Sen. Dick Durbin (D-IL): ‚ÄúI can tell you we have had fencing in the past and I‚Äôm sure we will in the future.‚Äù (1/11/2019)

Rep. Tom O'Halleran (D-AZ): When asked if the congressman would support a bill that reopened the government even if it provided funding for a wall, O‚ÄôHalleran simply said he has supported funding for sections of a border wall in the past. (1/7/2019)
Rep. Thomas Suozzi (D-NY): "I would support some physical structures on the border." (7/20/2018)
Rep. Scott Peters (D-CA): "Or, it might be, a physical barrier, such as a levee or fence if that makes sense in some places."(1/11/2019)

Rep. Peter Welch (D-VT): [Welch] said it‚Äôs important to respond to the immigration crisis in the southwestern U.S., but that proper security comes in different forms, including a physical barrier in some areas, but also ‚Äúvirtual walls‚Äù and patrols." (1/8/2019)
Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D-IL): said he's willing to cave on the wall if it means sparing hundreds of thousands of DACA recipients. "If that's their ransom call, I say pay it." (1/22/2019)

Rep. Kendra Horn (D-OK): "We need to get the government back open again and then let's have a broader conversation that puts everything on the table in terms of border security... That includes smart technology, that includes perhaps in some places a physical barrier."(1/23/2019)
Rep. John Sarbanes (D-MD): "Certain physical barriers can make sense along the border, and a lot of places you already have that." (1/11/2019)
Rep. Jim Costa (D-CA): "I have continually voted to improve border security, including authorizing construction of physical barriers where appropriate." (1/11/2019)
Rep. Jim Clyburn (D-SC), House Majority Whip: said there could be "secondary barriers" where necessary, including rebuilding existing physical barriers. (1/23/2019)

Rep. Jeff Van Drew (D-NJ): ‚ÄúWe are a nation of the rule of law, and we do need some type of barriers... In some places it may be electric, in some places it may be drone, in some it may be an actual wall. But we do need to ensure our security.‚Äù (1/20/2019)
Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY): "There are areas along the border where there are currently fences that are put up or barriers that are put up that need to be enhanced." (1/2/2019)
Rep. Eric Swalwell (D-CA): "Increase Border Patrol agents. Increase enforcement of overstay of visas. Increase use of technology and yes fencing where there are vulnerabilities.‚Äù (1/4/2019)
Rep. Ed Perlmutter (D-CO): ‚ÄúThere are a lot of ways to accomplish the border security ‚Äì through drones, through barriers, through a whole variety of things." (1/14/2019)
Rep. Bennie Thompson (D-MS), Chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee: "I would not rule out a wall in certain instances." (1/20/2019)
Rep. Ben McAdams (D-UT): ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think a border wall is immoral... There are places where it probably makes sense.‚Äù (1/21/2019)

"But the bottom line is that the ongoing escalation of prices by drug companies is simply unsustainable.

"We all recognize that research and development efforts on groundbreaking medications have made immeasurable contributions to the health of Americans, including new treatments and cures for diseases that have affected people for centuries."

"Let me be clear:  there are powerful interests here that do not want us to interfere with their massive profits.

"The pharmaceutical industry is one of the most profitable in the world‚Äîand one of the most POWERFUL.

"We have seen time after time that #drugcompanies make money hand over fist by raising the prices of their drugs‚Äîoften without justification, and sometimes overnight‚Äîwhile patients are left holding the bill."

"I have been waiting a very long time to hold this hearing.  

For the past decade, I have been trying to investigate the actions of #drugcompanies for all sorts of drugs‚Äîold and new, generic and brand-name."
"We also value the expert testimony of Dr. Jerry Anderson, Dr. Aaron Kesselheim, and Dr. Avik Roy."

"I also want to thank our other witnesses for being here today.  

We are grateful to have Dr. Catherine Georges of @AARP to speak on behalf of America‚Äôs #seniors. "
"So, when you testify here today, you are representing thousands and thousands of your fellow Americans who are suffering from the same worsening problem. "

‚Äúhave reported using less insulin than prescribed.‚Äù

"Ms. Worsham, it‚Äôs not easy to testify before Congress, and you are very courageous.

You are not alone. "

"The first witness to testify before the Oversight Committee is Antroinette Worsham.

"Two weeks ago, the Committee launched an investigation into #prescriptiondrugprices to determine why #drugcompanies are increasing prices so dramatically, how #drugcompanies are using the proceeds, and what steps can be taken to reduce #prescriptiondrugprices."

"But today, for our first hearing, I wanted to focus on one of the biggest problems facing American families across the country‚Äîthe actions of #drugcompanies that have been AGGRESSIVELY increasing prices on existing drugs and setting higher launch prices for new drugs!"
"And the latest of #PresidentTrump‚Äôs longtime advisers has been INDICTED on criminal charges."

"Until last Friday, the federal government was in the middle of the LONGEST #shutdown in U.S. history.

"Before we begin, I acknowledge that there is A LOT going on right now‚Äîhere on Capitol Hill and across the country."

"Today, we will examine the actions of #drugcompanies in raising #prescriptiondrugprices in the United States, as well as the effects of these actions on federal and state budgets and on American families."
"I know we are taking on a lot today, but I truly believe this is one of the most important issues facing our constituents, and it is one that demands immediate attention!"

The barrier to lowering CO2 isn't asset dispatch, but asset construction.  Once you build a zero/low carbon energy source it tends to outcompete traditional sources on the margin because it costs less to run.  So the right policy tool is one that leads to new asset construction.

Two weeks ago, Senator @PattyMurray and I took the first step by introducing legislation that will extend funding for community health centers for five years at $4 billion a year in mandatory funding.

In Fiscal Year 2019, these centers received $4 billion in mandatory funding and $1.6 billion in discretionary funding. Congress has to act by the end of September to make sure community health centers continue to receive this federal funding and keep their doors open.
Community health centers have also been an important part of combating the opioid crisis that has impacted virtually every community across the country. #OpioidCrisisResponse
There are about 1,400 federally-funded health centers that provide outpatient care to approximately 27 million people, including 400,000 Tennesseans, at about 12,000 sites across the United States.

Because the Lewis Health Center @MauryRegional is a community health center, they charge patients based on a sliding scale which means more people have access to and can afford health care close to home.

The old hospital building was turned into the Lewis Health Center @MauryRegional, a community health center which operates as something between a clinic and full hospital. Lewis Health Center estimates they can deal with about 90 percent of patients that walk in the door.
For example, in Tennessee, after Lewis County‚Äôs only hospital closed, the closest emergency room for its 12,000 residents was 30 minutes away.

Community health centers actually fit into a larger topic of great interest to this committee ‚Äì primary care. Today, we are talking about the community health centers where 27 million Americans receive their primary care and other services.
Today‚Äôs topic is extending federal funding for community health centers, as well as four other federal health programs, which are all set to expire at the end of September.

I will be working on these priorities with Ranking Member @PattyMurray, with members of the HELP Committee, and other senators interested reaching a result on lowering health care costs and updating the Higher Education Act.
